components.name: eucanetd
components.description: Used to track component level items associated with Edge.

fields.description:
Opening to track failures of net-test's test#8 in CI. It looks like after deleting a group which is referenced by another group in it's authorized rule list, instances run in the remaining group no-longer are accessible.  It looks like the correct rules are in place from a euca and mido perspective, restarting mido does not resolve the issue. 
Still debugging will hopefully post more info shortly...
Thanks!
-M

Definition of this test:
        Attempts to delete a security group which has been authorized by another security group.
        -Authorizes group1 access from group2
        -Validates connectivity for instances in group1 can be accessed from group2
        -Deletes group2, validates group1 still allows traffic from other authorized sources

This can reproduced quickly by re-building this job with the config_data of the cloud under test (see 'extra_args' for the minimum list of tests to run). This job seems to reproduce the failure about %30-50 of the times I've run it. 
http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/view/Matts/job/matt-net-test/19/

I'm seeing the following errors appear in the midolman.log(s) at the time of the test, not sure if they are relevant:

On CLC

fields.summary: VPC - Deleting a security group can leave VMs running in separate group unreachable

comments.body:
[~mclark]

I'm not able to reproduce this case manually, so I'd like to try trapping it in CI - I see the extra_opts from your test, but I don't know how to run a jenkins quicklaunch with said extra opts specified - can you quickly point me at the right doc and/or explain we can get to the point where the failure has occurred and then immediate pause the test so that I can investigate?

Best
-d

Quick update. 
-At least a portion of the edge failures I've now looked at were likely due to the test machine either; being nat'd, possibly changing it's IP (dhcp renew with new IP?), or changing the interface it was using to reach the VM's network during the test.  The ssh rule in place was for the single host of the test machine host/32.  I've changed this to wide open 0.0.0.0/0 for tcp/22 and this cleared up a fair amount of failures. 
-I've also reset the ssh connection when a failure is detected, in most/all cases this seems to resolve the remaining test failures. Not sure why the connection is dropped/lost in the failed cases though. 

Today the tests have been looking good. Not sure if our QA/DC had some network issues during the previous tests? Saturation from stress/scale tests maybe? 
I'm going to close this ticket until I can reproduce with the changes from above in the test. 
Thanks!
-M
